title: Whitbread says Brexit circus is putting business travellers off its Premier Inn hotels
text:
Whitbread, the FTSE-listed conglomerate behind Premier Inn hotels, said today that its profits were dented in the past six months amid 'challenging' UK trading conditions.

The firm, which sold off Costa Coffee last year in a £3.9billion deal with Coca Cola, said UK accommodation sales slumped by 3.6 per cent during the period, thanks to weaker demand in regional areas where Premier Inn has 80 per cent of its hotels.

It once again blamed the ongoing Brexit deadlock, which is taking its toll on consumer and business confidence and the wider travel industry.

The Premier Inn owner said UK accommodation sales slumped by 3.6% during the period

Whitbread said that the slowdown amid 'heightened political and economic uncertainty' was particularly noticeable among its business travellers and spread into the third quarter too.

'The continuing Brexit circus may be drawing more international attention to Britain but it's certainly not helping the country's travel market,' said Fiona Cincotta from City Index.

'Whitbread is more exposed to Brexit uncertainty than its UK peers because it has a larger chunk of the domestic business travel market and is more exposed to regional areas.'

Whitbread's half-year sales slipped 0.1 per cent to £1.08billion, while pre-tax profits fell 4.1 per cent to £236million as margins were squeezed.

A standard Premier Inn hotel room; demand among business customers is waning, it said

The group said fewer people made short-notice bookings, which tend to be more expensive, but added that, in London, Premier Inn sales grew by nearly 8 per cent thanks to recent expansion.

Alison Brittain, chief executive officer of Whitbread, said: 'We have delivered a resilient first half profit performance despite challenging market conditions in the UK.

One analyst said Whitbread is 'finding life tough' without its Costa business

'Shorter-term trading conditions in the UK regional market have been difficult, particularly in the business segment where we have a higher proportion of our revenue, whilst trading in London remained strong.

'Against this challenging backdrop, we have a number of activities under way which continue to build our brand strength as the UK's favourite hotel chain.'

The firm plans to generate greater demand for its hotels with new higher-spec 'Premier Plus' rooms in some of its locations.

It is also expanding its German division where it sees long-term growth opportunities.

Richard Hunter from Interactive Investor said Whitbread is 'finding life tough' without the 'significant buttress' of its former Costa business.

'The majority of the group is now represented by Premier Inn, and therefore largely in the hands of the hotels market. As business confidence starts to wane [...] two of the corporate expenditure lines which are traditionally sacrificed first in an effort to curb costs tend to be advertising and business travel.

'The latter has clear implications for Whitbread, even within its home market, and especially in its regional presence, where business stays are an important part of its model.'

Whitbread shares, which have declined by 13 per cent in the past six months, are down 0.1 per cent in early trading today at around £42.
